manpage.name: seccure
manpage.desc: SECCURE Elliptic Curve Crypto Utility for Reliable Encryption

synopsis.cmd: seccure-encrypt [-m maclen] [-c curve] [-i infile] [-o outfile] [-v] [-q] key
seccure-decrypt [-m maclen] [-c curve] [-i infile] [-o outfile] [-F pwfile] [-v] [-q]
seccure-sign [-f] [-b] [-c curve] [-s sigfile] [-i infile] [-o outfile] [-F pwfile] [-v] [-q]
seccure-verify [-f] [-b] [-c curve] [-s sigfile] [-i infile] [-o outfile] [-v] [-q] key [sig]

description.p: The seccure toolset implements a selection of asymmetric algorithms based on elliptic curve cryptography (ECC). In particular it offers public key encryption / decryption and signature generation / verification.

ECC schemes offer a much better key size to security ratio than classical systems (RSA, DSA). Keys are short enough to make direct specification of keys on the command line possible (sometimes this is more convenient than the management of PGP-like key rings). seccure builds on this feature and therefore is the tool of choice whenever lightweight asymmetric cryptography -- independent of key servers, revocation certificates, the Web of Trust or even configuration files -- is required.

section.name: Commands
section.p: seccure-key: Prompt for a passphrase and calculate the corresponding public key.
seccure-encrypt: Encrypt a message with public key key.
seccure-decrypt: Prompt for a passphrase and decrypt a seccure-encrypted message.
seccure-sign: Prompt for a passphrase and digitally sign a message.
seccure-verify: Verify signature sig with public key key.

optdesc.p: Use elliptic curve curve. Available are: secp112r1, secp128r1, secp160r1, secp192r1/nistp192, secp224r1/nistp224, secp256r1/nistp256, secp384r1/nistp384 and secp521r1/nistp521. The curve name may be abbreviated by any non-ambiguous substring (for instance it is suggested to specify p224 for the secp224r1/nistp224 curve). The default curve is p160, which provides reasonable security for everyday use. (See also HOW TO CHOOSE THE CURVE.)
Don't prompt for a passphrase; instead, take the first text line of pwfile.

Set the MAC length to maclen bits. Only multiples of 8 in the range from 0 to 256 are allowed. The default MAC length is 80 bits, which provides a reasonable level of integrity protection for everyday use.
Read from infile instead of STDIN.
Write to outfile instead of STDOUT.
For seccure-sign: Write signature to sigfile instead of STDERR.
For seccure-verify: Read signature from sigfile instead of using sig.
Filter mode: Copy all data read from STDIN verbatim to STDOUT.
Binary mode: Read/write signatures as binary strings. This leads to very compact signatures.
Verbose mode: Print some extra information.
Quiet mode: Disable all unnecessary output.

section.name: How to choose the curve
section.p: The number in the names of the curves measures their security level. Rule of thumb: the workload to 'break' a k-bit curve is 2^(k/2) approximately (example: it takes about 2^112 steps to break secp224r1). If the 80 bit security of the default curve doesn't seem sufficient, choosing a stronger curve (p192 and upwards) may, of course, be considered. But the suggestion remains: p160 offers reasonable security for everyday use. Warning: the curves p112 and p128 do not satisfy demands for long-time security.

section.name: Algorithms
section.p: seccure uses derivated versions of the ECIES (Elliptic Curve Integrated Encryption Scheme) and the ECDSA (Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Standard) as encryption and signature scheme, respectively. For the symmetric parts (bulk encryption, hashing, key derivation, HMAC calculation) seccure builds on AES256 (in CTR mode), SHA256 and SHA512.
